status_message:
Burning #paperofferings to deceased #ancestors is a common practice in China

and nearby countries including #Vietnam and #Cambodia. 

Workshop artisans specialise in paper replicas of real life pleasures,

such as iPads, luxury cars, companions and even airplanes.

Vietnamese authorities estimate some 50,000 tons of paper

are burnt during religious periods every year. 

Vietnam authorities have plead for people to spend less on offerings,

with the burnt offerings a seasonal source of urban pollution.

But old habits die hard, with many continuing to honour their dead relatives

in return for blessings, luck and spiritual overwatch.

status_message:
#Archery in #Indonesia, called Jemparingan, is done with a twist.

Or cross legged, to be exact.

#Jemparingan archers fire their arrows while seated, crossed-legged.

Despite their unconventional stance, Indonesian archers are no less accurate.

Indonesian archers won an Olympic silver medal ini the 1988 Seoul Games.

The unique archery style native to Java nearly disappeared after the death of its greatest patron, Duke Paku Alam VII in 1990.

Yet eager interest among youths keeps the centuries old hobby of the nobility alive.

Chinese diver #HeZi missed out on the gold medal for the #3mspringboard event Sunday, settling for silver after being beat by compatriot Shi Tingmao. 

He Zi's disappointment was washed away after her boyfriend Qin Kai, part of China's men's diving team, surprised her with a marriage #proposal after she stepped down from the medal podium.

Qin kneeled down with a #diamondring and proposed, with He nodding in agreement in front of millions of viewers. 

He's yes was cheered on by her fellow competitors, with the silver medalist remarking her engagement made up for her loss.

Sing like a superstar — #AugmentedReality reaches KTVs

#Karaoke lounges in #Shenzhen are using Augmented Reality (AR) technology to offer a new experience in the highly popular Asian urban past time.  

Singers fronting a green screen can find themselves performing in front of stunning virtual background at Karaoke, or KTV lounges, which are as popular in Asia as bars are in the west.

 The visual effect transforms simple lounge singing into a superstar celebrity performance.
The KTV enhancements are just one among many first steps for AR, which promises to revolutionize entertainment, advertisement and education.

Video from CCTV
link_name: Sing like a superstar -Augmented Reality reaches KTVs

The sanshin, a unique #Japanese instrument, is a three-stringed banjo with a head made from stretched snake skin.

The instrument produces a contagious and soulful sound that can be equally mournful and joyous.

It can be heard playing at weddings and other celebrations in Japan's #Okinawa region.

Recently, the sanshin has made the transition to popular musical styles, including rock. The instrument has an increasing following among young people in the country.
link_name: Okinawa's Snakeskin banjo stands test of time

Chinese team wins Ashtray Drag Race award

Team Ocean Striker from #ShangdongUniversity of Art & Design has won the #AshtrayDragRace award in the #FormulaEinternational rubber band-powered racecar competition in Pasadena, #California.
Of the 16 teams that competed in the race on Thursday, five were from China. Team Ocean Striker also won the best design award. 
The race was sponsored by the ArtCenter College of Design, one of the top design schools. Judges included Art Center President Lorne Buchman, and design representatives from the Walt Disney Company, Honda and many other companies.
According to the ArtCenter's website, the annual Formula E race provides corporate and student teams with valuable experience in product development, engineering, team building and fabrication while pushing their ability to find solutions under pressure, recover from failure and ultimately win.''
link_name: Chinese team wins Ashtray Drag Race award

Thailand's military junta has been unable to quell an Islamic insurgency in the southern provinces, but it is unclear if the blasts are connected.

Pokemon Fever -Pikachu parade in Japan

Hundreds of Pokemon fans gathered in Yokohama, southwest of Tokyo, on Sunday to join an annual Pikachu parade as the global Pokemon Go phenomenon soars in popularity.

Some 50 life-size Pikachu characters marched along the city's waterfront street as onlookers took pictures and videos under the scorching sun.

Since its global launch, Pokemon Go has sparked a worldwide frenzy among users, who have taken to the streets with their smartphones.

Pokemon has been popular in Japan since the first game launched in 1996 for Nintendo's iconic Game Boy console. 

It expanded into other media, most notably a wildly popular animated TV show, and its popularity has never waned.
link_name: Pokemon Fever  Pikachu parade in Japan

The traditional Chinese lunar calendar divides the year into 24 solar terms. #StartofAutumn, (Chinese: 立秋), the 13th solar term of the year, begins this year on Aug 7 and ends on Aug 20.

Start of Autumn reflects the end of summer and the beginning of autumn. The fruitful season is approaching.

In China, the #24solarterms were created thousands of years ago to guide agricultural production. But solar term culture is still useful today to guide people's lives through special foods, cultural ceremonies and even healthy living tips that correspond with each term.

The following are 9 things you should know about Start of Autumn. http://bit.ly/2aDvBCO
link_name: Culture Insider | 9 things you may not know about Start of Autumn

Few visitors to Hong Kong miss a trip up Victoria Peak, but few choose to walk up. There are many routes, the gentlest starts on the backside in Pok Fu Lam past the reservoir and along a narrow road. Once you reach the bustling square, find Lugard road to escape the crowds and enjoy a one hour looping road that affords spectacular views around the peak. I started after lunch, timing the walk to finish back at the galleria at sunset to watch the lights come up over the city followed by dinner with a view and a bus home. 

Take a bus to Pok Fu Lam reservoir stop and follow the road up into the country park. Continue up to the Peak following the signs until you reach the Galleria. Look for Lugard road on your left and walk the loop back to the Galleria where there is transport back to the city.
link_name: Victoria Peak – a hidden country walk above the city

status_message: #GermanChancellor #AngelaMerkel will visit China again on June 12. During her ninth China trip, both leaders will step up to connect the two countries' national manufacturing strategies, #Industry40 and #MadeinChina2025.  #statevisit #friendsreunion

For the love of the pandas 

Mei Yan has been working at the Chengdu Research Base which breeds Giant Pandas for the past eight years. As of now, she helps feed 50 pandas.Born in 1986, Mei is a typical Chengdu girl, optimistic, cheerful with a smile similar to that of a cute panda. Caring for pandas is hard work. Every day, she has to prepare bamboo for the pandas to eat and then clear away hundred kilos of fecal matter. An adult giant panda eats around 100 kilos of bamboo shoots. Young pandas may look cute, but have sharp claws and teeth. Often Mei is bitten and scratched by the pandas. But despite the problems, Mei still feels a great sense of accomplishment, watching the cubs grow. "They are like my family," she says.

status_message:
Lamma is the biggest of the car free outlying islands, making it perfect for a full day of exploration on foot. 

My root started at the northern tip and took me through thick jungle to Hung Shing Ye beach where the walk switches to a coastal hike to the fishing village of Sok Kwu Wan. If you are lucky, or unlucky depending on your love for all things wild, you may see a wild boar or python snake. Both are common sightings in Lamma's outback. No need for a pack lunch on this trip with plenty of restaurants offering great seafood choices. There is a loop in the southern part of the island if you want to spend time at the beach or a walk to the southern trip where a ferry returns you to Hong Kong island.

status_message:
There's an easy and a hard way to ascend Hong Kong's second tallest peak. I opted for the cable car that gets you half way. After a quick stop in Ngong Ping to see the Big Buddha statue, it's a steep two-hour climb up for lunch at the top of the mountain. Allow time to take in the panoramic sweeping coastal views. There are paths in every direction for the walk home. A long path through to Mui Wo, a southern route past the Shek Pik reservoir to Tung Wan or a shortcut back to Tung Chung. With the cable car not starting before 10AM you will need to be fast to take the longer routes.

Start at the cable car from Tung Chung to Ngong Ping. Walk through the village past the Big Buddha and onto the wisdom path until you see signs for the peak. From there continue along the Lantau trail until you reach Tung Chung road where you can get a bus back to Tung Chung.

status_message:
China has surpassed the United States to become the world's largest country exporting #culturalgoods in 2013, a latest UNESCO report said.

By 2013, the total value of China's cultural exports stood at $60.1 billion, more than double that of the United States' $27.9 billion, according to the report by the UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS).

"Trade in cultural goods totaled $212.8 billion in 2013, nearly double the amount in 2004. This is further evidence of the critical role cultural industries play in today's global economy," said Silvia Montoya, director of the UIS.

Here are the top 10 country exporting culture goods in the world.  bit.ly/1TQbu6R

A flower bun art festival is ongoing in Hebi city of #Henan province, which puts on display more than 300 pieces of creative flower buns from Shaanxi, Shanxi, Anhui, Henan provinces in Central China.

The age of the creators ranges from 8 to 66 years old. Flower buns, an edible art form, is a traditional folk art in China with a long history dating back to the ancient Han Dynasty. #Video Munao Zongge Festival is the grandest traditional festival of Jingpos in Dehong prefecture of #Yunnan. It is an ethnic carnival in west China, renowned as "the dance of paradise" and "dance of thousands of people".

#MunaoZonggeFestival falls around 15th day of the 1st month by lunar calendar every year, when every village will celebrate the festival. On that day, tens of thousands of people dance together with the same drumbeat. 

Munao Zongge festival has already been listed among the first batch of nationally non-material cultural legacy.

status_message:
Egg carving master challenges Guinness World Record

Egg craftsman Kong Bin has been in love with carving since childhood. Creating delicate art gives him great pleasure and he hopes to apply for the intangible cultural heritage to pass on the traditional art.

"Beating the #GuinnessWorldRecord in #eggcarving is nothing difficult for me. I've managed to bore more than 7,665 holes in an egg, which is the current record," he said.

To produce such art, a complicated set of procedures have to be followed: choosing the right egg, extracting the yolk, removing the membrane inside the egg as well as sterilizing and bleaching. Read more: http://bit.ly/1QnSagt

status_message:
Antarctica wins affluent Chinese tourists' heart

The number of adventurous Chinese tourists visiting Antarctica has jumped 30 times in the past seven years – so much so that it has become a trend for affluent Chinese tourists to chase penguins during Spring Festival. 

A total of 3,042 Chinese visitors went to Antarctica from 2014 to 2015, according to visitor totals released by the International Association of Antarctica Tour Operators (IAATO). That's up from  less than 100 back in 2008, according to Hurtigruten China.

China ranked as the fourth largest source country to Antarctica, following the United States, Australia and the United Kingdom. 
HHtravel, a high-end travel service provider under Ctrip, said Spring Festival is the best season for Antarctica fans in China. 
October to February is summer in Antarctica and most Chinese have a seven-day holiday for the festival, an HHtravel spokesperson said.

"Wealth should not be the only index to evaluate a country's development path, and economic output should not be the only aim of development," said Dr Li Shidong, who headed the study.

The  #Milken Institute, an independent economic think tank in the United States, has released its first report ranking Chinese cities on their economic performance.

A total of 266 Chinese cities at prefecture level and above were studied, divided into two groups, one consisting of 34 first-and-second-tier cities and a second echelon of small-and-medium-sized ones, including 232 third-tier cities.

The rankings are based on actual economic performance, rather than projected success. The index considers job and income growth, gross regional product (GRP), and foreign direct investment (FDI), as well as the strength of high value-added industries in each city.

The following are the top 10 best-performing large cities in China.

#Live Car used in attacks found in Paris suburb: police

 A black Seat car used by gunmen who fired at people in restaurants during the attacks in Paris on Friday has been found in the eastern suburb of Montreuil, police said Sunday.

Six people close to Omar Ismail Mostefai, who took part in the killings at the Bataclan concert hall and the first of Friday's attackers to be identified, have been detained, including his father, brother and sister-in-law, judicial and police sources said. Via AFP #ParisAttacks #PrayforParis

#Live Israel gives France intelligence on Paris attackers - media

Israel's spy services are helping France investigate the Paris gun and bomb attacks, Israeli media said, with one radio station suggesting the assistance drew on surveillance of militant groups in Syria and Iraq.

Israel had no advance warning of Friday's rampage that killed at least 129 people, but within hours of it happening gave France information about some of the Islamic State militants who claimed to have carried it out, the top-rated television station Channel Two said, quoting an unnamed senior Israeli official.

Without providing details, Channel Two said Israeli intelligence saw a "clear operational link" between the attack in the French capital, Thursday's Beirut suicide bombings and the Oct. 31 downing of a Russian airliner in the Egyptian Sinai. Via Reuters #ParisAttacks #PrayforParis

#Live Police hold people close to one Paris attacker - source

Police were holding for questioning the father and brother of a man who took part in Friday's attacks in Paris, French media reported on Sunday.

A judicial source confirmed police were holding people close to one of the attackers, seven of whom died in the assault, which has been claimed by Islamic State. Police have identified one of the men as a Frenchman, on whom authorities had a dossier that marked him as a potential Islamist militant.

The reports said searches were also being conducted in the relatives' homes in the northeastern Aube region and in Essonne, south of Paris. Via Reuters #ParisAttacks #PrayforParis

#Live Deadly Paris attacks reveal 'next stage of IS': experts

The Islamic State group's ability to carry out the deadly Paris attacks that it has claimed reveals the growing sophistication and reach of the global jihadist network, analysts said Saturday.

Experts say they demonstrate IS's evolution from localized operations in Iraq and Syria to the West. "The push to France likely represents the next stage of IS," said Clint Watts, a senior fellow at the Foreign Policy Research Institute.

"We'll see them increasingly move away from conventional and insurgent operations in Iraq and Syria and more towards terrorist attacks in their extended network," he said.  #ParisAttacks #PrayforParis

#VietnamVisit Vietnam "Top to Bottom" is a train journey through Vietnam on the "reunification express".The train runs from the capital Hanoi in the North to Ho Chi Minh City former Saigon and capital of the South Vietnam during the American - Vietnamese war. In French writer Marguerite Duras'snovel Lover,the author introduces the journey as a flowof live French flair, ancient but mellow, vague but brokenhearted. 

During the French colonial period, it took about 40 to build the railway. It's a single-track rail and serves as themain rail connection forthe country. It covers 1726 km of land.And 191 of the 278 train stations in Vietnam are located along this line. During the American Vietnamese war, while the country was divided in two parts, the line was interrupted and seriously damaged by the war. The route reopened at the end of the war and is unofficially called the reunification line to set forth the reunification of the country.

Nowadays, the meaning of its historic background gradually fades away. Instead, this "reunification express" travels between new city and ancient town. It'sconsidered to be a symbol of reminiscence. From its stations to its attendants, everything stayed nearly the same as what they were ten year ago. The green train hisses off the station forthousands of miles, through troubled times and flourished ages, through the poor and the rich.

Next station: Future.
link_name: Top to bottom: train journey through Vietnam

status_message:
#ChinaDailyOpinion People's exchanges vital

Owing to vastly different cultures, traditions and political institutions, China and the United States have a long way to go to deepen their cooperation. Unlike Washington which often seeks to "change" other countries (including China), China is committed to the idea of "harmony in difference". That is what makes it possible for both countries to seek common ground while shelving their differences.

People-to-people exchanges, especially those between younger generations from both countries, should play a key role in bilateral communications. Many of the US politicians and media professionals who constantly question almost everything that happens in China grew up during the Cold War, and are thus less likely to abandon their deep-rooted parochial mentality. Continue reading: http://bit.ly/1LHKPjI 

The author is a professor of US studies at China Foreign Affairs University, and a Fulbright Visiting Scholar at the School of Advanced International Studies of Johns Hopkins University.

Remnant of war becomes family treasure
During the 1930s and 40s, many Jewish refugees fled to and found refuge in Shanghai. And evidence of that bond they formed with their adopted city can still be seen today. An old style residential neighborhood built in 1929 in Shanghai is full of "lane houses." During World War II, many Jewish refugees lived there. There were about 100 Jewish households living in the lane at that time, even more than local residents, so it was known as "the Lane of Foreigners." http://ow.ly/RI35L

The video is designed to promote China-ROK friendship before the V-Day victory commemorations through both countries' youngsters. China's southernmost city of Sansha, which administers a number of South China Sea islands, will soon launch waste treatment facilities as local authorities intensify efforts to protect the local maritime environment.

The city government will soon bring into use a wastewater treatment plant and a garbage treatment plant on Yongxing Island, the Sansha government seat, its news office said in a statement on Friday, which was the third anniversary of the city's establishment.

China launches two satellites for independent navigation system
XICHANG, Sichuan - China successfully launched two satellites for its indigenous global navigation and positioning network at 8:29 pm Beijing Time Saturday, the launch center said.

Launched from the Xichang Satellite Launch Center in the southwestern China's Sichuan Province, the two satellites were the 18th and 19th for the Beidou Navigation Satellite system, China's homegrown navigation system.

They were sent into their preset orbits by a Long March-3B/Expedition-1 carrier rocket 3.5 hours after the launch, the center said.

Expedition-1, or Yuanzheng-1, is an independent aircraft installed on the carrier rocket with the ability of sending one or more spacecraft into different orbits in space.

Audit finds 25% of #lottery funds were used illegally

A quarter of China's lottery funds have been misappropriated, according to the country's first large-scale audit of the industry, which has called for a prompt cleanup.

A total of 16.9 billion yuan ($2.72 billion) in lottery funds were used illegally, the National Audit Office said on Thursday. This represented more than 25 percent of all lottery funds received between 2012 and last year.

A report on the office's website said the audit－carried out in November and December－covered 18 provinces and 228 lottery sale institutions nationwide, as well as 4,956 lottery projects involving public welfare funds.

Auditors found the funds were misused through the purchase and establishment of office buildings, or had been embezzled. Some officials in lottery shops also benefitted illegally from the funds through fake lottery projects, the report said.

Chinese official says key China-US dialogue promotes relations #SED

Chinese Vice-Premier Wang Yang said Monday that the China-US Strategic and Economic Dialogue (S&ED) has helped the world's two largest economies identify and expand common interests and strengthen bilateral relations.

In an op-ed carried by The Wall Street Journal, Wang said the key China-US dialogue has helped the two countries effectively manage differences and minimize their impact on bilateral relations, and also helped US leaders and the public learn more about 21st-century China.

The dialogue is a sign of the growing maturity of China-US relations, Wang said, noting that bilateral trade has doubled over the past nine years and China has become one of the fastest-growing export markets for the United States.

Over the past six years, direct investment from Chinese companies to the United States has increased fivefold, creating more than 80,000 jobs across the country, he said, adding that there's significant room for growth if there are fewer obstacles to Chinese investment in the United States.

China spends more on medical aid

The Chinese government spent 109.5 billion yuan (17.9 bln US dollars) aiding people who can't afford medical services during the 2009-2014 period, an official said on Wednesday. #China #HealthCare

Government spending on medical aid rose by an annual average of 13.8 percent during the period, said Jiang Yu with the Ministry of Finance.

China established a national medical assistance system in 2008, allocating money to help disadvantaged people purchase medical insurance and to subsidize healthcare not included in insurance programs.

In 2014, the nation spent 25.4 billion yuan on such subsidies, benefiting 102 million people.

Currently, 63 percent of the funding comes from the central government, while local governments and donations contribute 32 percent and 5 percent respectively.

The Ministry of Environmental Protection has imposed a total fine of 112 million yuan ($18 million) on 160 cases nationwide in the first four months of this year. #Environment #China

After the Environmental Protection Law came into effect, there has been a 515 percent increase in cases in March and April from the first two months this year, Zou Shoumin, chief of Environmental Inspection Bureau of the ministry, told Yicai.com on Monday.

The highest fine of an individual case was 15.8 million yuan on Shaanxi Coal and Chemical Industry Group Co which failed to correct the problem of discharging excessive pollutants.

China's central Henan province handled 26 such cases in the first four months slapping a 29-million-yuan fine.

Enterprises have stepped up investment in environmental protection after the strict law enforcement, said Zou.

[Xinhua]

[Xinhua]

[CFP]
